Aim 3) This will be a select group of microbial culture samples that will undergo imaging with SEM-EDX, FTIR-microscopy, and x-ray fluorescence microscopy via EMSL and the eBERlight program to characterize rare earth element and other elemental localization in cells. These samples will originate from cultures grown anaerobically in synthetic media representative of mines, landfills, and e-waste contaminated sites with high concentrations of rare earth elements.

Aim 1) We estimate that 30 samples of liquid and solid industrial waste will be sent to EMSL for analytical chemistry. This will involve samples from e-waste recycling facilities including shredder dust, shredded waste, and effluent. This will include samples from landfills including leachate. This will include samples from mine tailings including REE-containing ores. These samples are being sent for ICP-MS, ion chromatography, C, H, N, S analyses, and GC-MS.

Aims 2) These samples will come from enrichment cultures grown in liquid medium in the lab. This medium will mimic the chemistry of contaminated effluent, leachate, and mine tailings, and will be high in metals in addition to rare earth elements. These samples would constitute a select few that will be sent for ICP-MS analyses to confirm rare earth element concentrations.

Non-pathogenic wild type Caenorhabditis elegans culture and 12 non-pathogenic environmental bacterial strains, the CeMbio C. elegans synthetic microbiome, will be sent to EMSL for building the plant-soil-nematode-microbe systems on the SubTap platforms. The C. elegans strain was acquired from the Caenorhabditis Genetic Center at University of Minnesota, and the CeMbio microbiome is a generous gift from Prof. Fan Zhang at Louisiana State University. We can either ship live culture to be directly used for setting up the experiment or ship frozen stocks to revive at EMSL for bacterial culture. We can also ship the nutrient medium plates needed to EMSL or prepare it onsite.

Extracted metabolites from soil samples and agar pads from nematode-growth medium, bacterial-grown plates and C. elegans plates. We will prepare four replicates for each group and repeat the experiment twice, resulting in 32 samples in total. These samples will be collected from lab cultures and metabolites will be extracted in Qiu Lab at Michigan State University. We expect to ship samples to EMSL in Winter 2024/Spring 2025.

Switchgrass root-tips will be collected on the Agricultural Research Station, Nashville, TN.  Root-tips will be sectioned and  placed on PENN or ITO slides, and shipped to EMSL facility for proteomics analysis.  Proteins will be extracted from root cap/rhizosphere samples and shipped to EMSL as dehydrated protein powder. 
 Samples to be analyzed include:  
A. Four cell types of root-tips  including the apical meristem (PM), the primary meristem, transition zone cells and elongation zone cells. Five biological replicates will be included for each cell type, heat-treated and the non-heat-treated conditions, and the three-sample collection timepoints (Spring, Summer, Fall).  120 each for  bulk TDP LCMS, MALDI proteoform imaging, and  MALDI -proteomics imaging. 
B. At each of the three sample points, five replicates of root cap/soil samples will be collected from heat-treated and non-heat-treated soil. 30 samples will be analyzed using the UPLC system coupled with a hybrid quadrupole/Orbitrap mass spectrometer.

We will conduct a two-part experiment to track the fate of mineral-associated organic matter carbon (MAOM-C) in the presence of oxalic acid and biochar. In the first part, an adsorption experiment will be performed with the goal of preparing and characterizing 13C-labeled MAOM. 

The second part of the experiment will comprise a stable isotope probing (SIP) experiment to trace labelled C and evaluate the impact of biochar on improving retention of freshly added organic material. For this experiment, 80-g soil samples (previously collected from the DOE-funded Great Lakes Bioenergy Center in Michigan) will be inoculated with MAOM-13C and subjected to various treatments in a 2 × 4 factorial design (performed in-house). 

We request that EMSL perform the following analyses to support this research: (i) EA-IRMS of mineral samples (n=27), (ii) GC-IRMS of gas samples (n= 48), (iii) liquid-state 13C-NMR of in-house-extracted porewater (n=48), (iv) solid-state 13C-NMR of soil samples (n=48), and (v) XRD of mineral samples (n=6). All samples sent to EMSL will be 13C-labeled.

Aim 2) Hundreds of enrichment cultures will be initiated using biomass sampled from habitats with high levels of rare earth elements. These cultures will be grown in synthetic effluent, ocean water, and freshwater, amended with different rare earth elements and organic carbon sources. We are requesting ICP-MS analyses to measure rare earth element concentrations in aqueous samples obtained for a subset of cultures. We are also requesting GC-MS and LC-MS analyses to measure changes to carbon sources amended to select cultures and abiotic controls over time. Samples will be prepared for analyses in Dr. Gregoire and/or Dr. Martinez-Gomez's labs. These enrichments will last several weeks to months. During that time we anticipate sending 180 samples from biotic treatments and 20 samples from abiotic treatments for analysis via each method to capture multiple time points. This total has been revised to 200 samples per year per analytical method following comments from EMSL staff at the LOI stage.

Aim 2) Hundreds of enrichment cultures will be initiated using biomass sampled from habitats with high levels of rare earth elements. These cultures will be grown in synthetic effluent, ocean water, and freshwater, amended with different rare earth elements and organic carbon sources. We are requesting metagenomic and metatranscriptomic sequencing through JGI to characterize these cultures. DNA and RNA extractions will be carried out in Dr. Gregoire and/or Dr. Martinez-Gomez's labs. We are requesting the following sequencing through JGI; genomic: 80 samples on 2 flow lanes, transcriptomic: 80 samples on 2 flow lanes, both at 45 Gb a sample for a total of 7.2 Tb. We request this sequencing be carried out on the Illumina HiSeq 4000 platform. Note that this puts the total sequencing request associated with this proposal at 9.9 Tb out of the 10 Tb cap.

Aim 1) Several hundred grams of solid e-waste samples, effluent, and magnet swarf will be obtained from Ontario, Canada, and California, USA to support this work. DNA and RNA will be extracted from these samples in Dr. Gregoire and/or Dr. Martinez-Gomez's labs to prepare them for metagenomic and metatranscriptomic sequencing at JGI. We are requesting the following sequencing services; genomic: 30 samples on 1 flow lane, transcriptomic: 30 samples on 1 flow lane, both at 45 Gb a sample for a total of 2.7 Tb of sequencing. We are requesting this sequencing be carried out using the Illumina HiSeq 4000 platform.

Aim 1) Several hundred grams of solid e-waste samples, effluent, and magnet swarf will be obtained from recycling facilities in Ontario, Canada, and California, USA to support this work. We are requesting total metals and inorganic nutrient analyses for these solid and aqueous samples via ICP-MS and a C, H, N, S, analyzer. Sample preparation will be carried out in the labs of Dr. Gregoire and/or Dr. Martinez-Gomez. We anticipate providing 30 samples for each analysis.

Aim 2) Hundreds of enrichment cultures will be initiated using biomass sampled from habitats with high levels of rare earth elements. These cultures will be grown in synthetic effluent, ocean water, and freshwater, amended with different rare earth elements and organic carbon sources. We are requesting that select cultures be further examined via scanning electron microscopy coupled to energy-dispersed X-ray to characterize physical interactions between cells and rare earth elements.

Aim 1) Several hundred grams of solid e-waste samples, effluent, and magnet swarf will be obtained from recycling facilities in Ontario, Canada, and California, USA to support this work. We are requesting carbon source analyses on environmental samples and abiotic controls via GC-MS and LC-MS. Sample preparation will be carried out in the labs of Dr. Gregoire and/or Dr. Martinez-Gomez. We anticipate providing 120 samples for each analysis.
